hints.label: def-observable-dependent-closure
hints.title: Observable-Dependent Computational Closure
hints.content:
2885: :label: def-observable-dependent-closure
2886: 
2887: Let $\mathcal{O}: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ be a physical observable, and $\pi: \Omega_{\text{micro}} \to \Omega_{\text{macro}}$ a coarse-graining.
2888: 
2889: **$\mathcal{O}$-Computational Closure:** The coarse-graining satisfies **computational closure with respect to $\mathcal{O}$** if:
2890: 
2891: $$
2892: \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}(X_{k+\ell}) \mid H_k^{\text{macro}}] = \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}(X_{k+\ell}) \mid H_k^{\text{micro}} \text{ projected to macro}]
2893: $$
2894: 
2895: for all future times $\ell > 0$, where $H_k$ denotes the history up to time $k$.
2896: 
2897: **Error bound:**
2898: 
2899: $$
2900: \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O} \mid H_k^{\text{macro}}] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O} \mid H_k^{\text{micro}}] \right| \le L_{\mathcal{O}} \cdot \varepsilon_{\text{lump}}
2901: $$
2902: 
2903: where:
hints.raw_directive:
2882: So far, closure has been defined in terms of **all possible future observations**. In practice, we care about specific observables.
2883: 
2884: :::{prf:definition} Observable-Dependent Computational Closure
2885: :label: def-observable-dependent-closure
2886: 
2887: Let $\mathcal{O}: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ be a physical observable, and $\pi: \Omega_{\text{micro}} \to \Omega_{\text{macro}}$ a coarse-graining.
2888: 
2889: **$\mathcal{O}$-Computational Closure:** The coarse-graining satisfies **computational closure with respect to $\mathcal{O}$** if:
2890: 
2891: $$
2892: \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}(X_{k+\ell}) \mid H_k^{\text{macro}}] = \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}(X_{k+\ell}) \mid H_k^{\text{micro}} \text{ projected to macro}]
2893: $$
2894: 
2895: for all future times $\ell > 0$, where $H_k$ denotes the history up to time $k$.
2896: 
2897: **Error bound:**
2898: 
2899: $$
2900: \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O} \mid H_k^{\text{macro}}] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O} \mid H_k^{\text{micro}}] \right| \le L_{\mathcal{O}} \cdot \varepsilon_{\text{lump}}
2901: $$
2902: 
2903: where:
2904: - $L_{\mathcal{O}}$ is the Lipschitz constant of $\mathcal{O}$

hints.label: thm-observable-closure-hierarchy
hints.title: Observable Closure Hierarchy
hints.content:
2919: :label: thm-observable-closure-hierarchy
2920: 
2921: For observables $\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2$ with Lipschitz constants $L_1 < L_2$:
2922: 
2923: $$
2924: \text{If } \mathcal{O}_2\text{-closure holds, then } \mathcal{O}_1\text{-closure holds}
2925: $$
2926: 
2927: **Proof:** By the error bound:
2928: 
2929: $$
2930: \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_1] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_1^{\text{macro}}] \right| \le L_1 \varepsilon_{\text{lump}} \le L_2 \varepsilon_{\text{lump}} = \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_2] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_2^{\text{macro}}] \right|
2931: $$
hints.raw_directive:
2916: **Theorem (Observable Hierarchy):**
2917: 
2918: :::{prf:theorem} Observable Closure Hierarchy
2919: :label: thm-observable-closure-hierarchy
2920: 
2921: For observables $\mathcal{O}_1, \mathcal{O}_2$ with Lipschitz constants $L_1 < L_2$:
2922: 
2923: $$
2924: \text{If } \mathcal{O}_2\text{-closure holds, then } \mathcal{O}_1\text{-closure holds}
2925: $$
2926: 
2927: **Proof:** By the error bound:
2928: 
2929: $$
2930: \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_1] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_1^{\text{macro}}] \right| \le L_1 \varepsilon_{\text{lump}} \le L_2 \varepsilon_{\text{lump}} = \left| \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_2] - \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{O}_2^{\text{macro}}] \right|
2931: $$

hints.label: alg-closure-verification
hints.title: Multi-Scale Closure Verification
hints.content:
2945: :label: alg-closure-verification
2946: 
2947: **Input:**
2948: - Micro-scale simulation data $\{Z_k^{\text{micro}}\}_{k=0}^T$ (e.g., full swarm or Fractal Set)
2949: - Coarse-graining map $\pi: \Omega_{\text{micro}} \to \Omega_{\text{macro}}$ (e.g., scutoid aggregation)
2950: - Observable $\mathcal{O}: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ (e.g., scutoid fraction $\phi$)
2951: - Target error tolerance $\epsilon_{\text{tol}}$
2952: 
2953: **Output:**
2954: - Closure verification: YES/NO
2955: - Error estimates: $\{\varepsilon_{\text{lump}}(b)\}$ for different block sizes $b$
2956: - Recommended block size $b^*$ achieving $\varepsilon_{\text{lump}} < \epsilon_{\text{tol}}$
2957: 
2958: :::{warning}
2959: **Computational Complexity:** Steps 4 and 5 (computing statistical complexity $C_\mu$ and Fisher distances $d_{\text{Fisher}}$) are **computationally intensive** and may be intractable for complex systems:
2960: 
2961: - **Step 4:** Computing $C_\mu = H(\Sigma_\varepsilon)$ requires identifying all causal states and their probabilities, which is **NP-hard** in the general case (estimating causal states from finite data is an open problem in computational mechanics).
2962: - **Step 5:** Computing Fisher distances requires estimating high-dimensional conditional probability distributions $P(F \mid \sigma)$ and their KL-divergences, which suffers from the curse of dimensionality.
hints.raw_directive:
2942: **Practical algorithm:** Given a Fragile Gas simulation, how do we **verify** that a coarse-graining satisfies computational closure?
2943: 
2944: :::{prf:algorithm} Multi-Scale Closure Verification
2945: :label: alg-closure-verification
2946: 
2947: **Input:**
2948: - Micro-scale simulation data $\{Z_k^{\text{micro}}\}_{k=0}^T$ (e.g., full swarm or Fractal Set)
2949: - Coarse-graining map $\pi: \Omega_{\text{micro}} \to \Omega_{\text{macro}}$ (e.g., scutoid aggregation)
2950: - Observable $\mathcal{O}: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ (e.g., scutoid fraction $\phi$)
2951: - Target error tolerance $\epsilon_{\text{tol}}$
2952: 
2953: **Output:**
2954: - Closure verification: YES/NO
2955: - Error estimates: $\{\varepsilon_{\text{lump}}(b)\}$ for different block sizes $b$
2956: - Recommended block size $b^*$ achieving $\varepsilon_{\text{lump}} < \epsilon_{\text{tol}}$
2957: 
2958: :::{warning}
2959: **Computational Complexity:** Steps 4 and 5 (computing statistical complexity $C_\mu$ and Fisher distances $d_{\text{Fisher}}$) are **computationally intensive** and may be intractable for complex systems:
2960: 
2961: - **Step 4:** Computing $C_\mu = H(\Sigma_\varepsilon)$ requires identifying all causal states and their probabilities, which is **NP-hard** in the general case (estimating causal states from finite data is an open problem in computational mechanics).
2962: - **Step 5:** Computing Fisher distances requires estimating high-dimensional conditional probability distributions $P(F \mid \sigma)$ and their KL-divergences, which suffers from the curse of dimensionality.
